text: Draft at Ei8ht Ball for Peanut-palooza. Pours an oily dark brown to black in color with a small khaki colored head. The aroma and flavor have big chocolate, dark fruit and barrel character, blackberry, raisins, whiskey, dark chocolate, light coffee, viscous, vanilla, this was a treat and I would like to try this again sometime.
Draft at Avenue Pub. Jet black color, brown head, see pic please. Huge bourbon aroma with vanilla, coffee, dates, raisins. Taste is big, boozy bourbon, coffee, vanilla. Sit close to the floor.
On draft. Black pour, with a tan head. Big whiskey, vanilla, smooth and creamy, roasty, burnt bread, milk chocolate, some chewy dark fruit, and a little boozy. Pretty nice.

tap at 2016 michigan winter beer festival. Near black with small head. Big old whiskey porter. Coffee and chocolate mixed with whiskey -- hard to complain about that combination. Relatively smooth for the ABV.
Draft at the Stone Pour it Black Event. Great black pour. beautiful head and nice nose. Flavors were lovely

On tap at Pats tap. Pours oily black with a light brown head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma is full of whiskey with a good amount of oak and a combination bitter dark grains and chocolate underlying. Flavor is full of whiskey with underlying notes of oak and bitter dark grains. Overly boozy.
Pours a dark maroon brown with no head. Oaky and vinous nose. Flavors are the same. Sweet with a fade of tartness for balance. Becomes rather astringent at the finish.

Draft at Gravity Taphouse - pours a dark brown with slight red hue . Soft oak , vanilla and sweet cherry aromas. Mild tartness from the cherries with some warming alcohol . Very good . 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap at Tumans in Chicago. I cant believe they gave me a whole pint of this stuff! Aroma is strong chocolate and malt. Flavor is a good balance of juicy slightly tart fruit, vanilla, and whisky barrel flavors. Barrel flavor isnt overwhelming as Traverse City Whisky is a fairly mild whisky and I dont think this beer was aged too long. I think thats a good thing though because I think a porter like this would easily overwhelmed and I like that you can still taste the base beer because it is a very good base beer.

Aroma is barrel, roasted malt, chocolate. Appearance is dark brown, light brown head. Taste is roasted malt, barrel, very nice. Mouthfeel is lovely, thick and nice carbonation. Overall, this is very very good.

Draft - 9oz pour turned out to be a 16oz pour - whoops. Nose is vanilla, oak, bourbon, weed (some dude near me), and fuzzy memories of being at Dark Lord. Sip ads roast, booze, more wood, chocolate and lactose. Incredibly smooth and easy to drink. Danj-juh-russ. A treat considering this place just ran out of the mango habanero. Gums are going numb. Fantastic! Chewy. Whiskey dominates but the chocolate puts up a great fight. Great balance in the flavors. I see a rum barrel version imminently made.

Draft at Flannys during a Bells tap takeover. Pungent aroma of very sweet whiskey with a sharp fresh oak tone  that woodiness increases to the point of dominance. Minor grassy note with hints of dark cherries and prunes. Pours glossy black with a swiftly disappearing khaki head. What a lovely complex and balanced taste: sweet and boozy whiskey blends with vanilla, charred barley, bakers chocolate, a slightly overpowering dry cedar-oaky finish. Proper body for a porter. The wood characteristics are a bit overt but otherwise it is quite enjoyable.

Draft to snifter at the Eccentric Cafe. Looks good; a slightly transparent dark cola with beige head that steadily dissipates into lacing. Smells great! Malty with notes of chocolate, caramel, vanilla, and oak alongside a nicely balanced mild to moderate cherry presence. Tastes like it smells, but not quite as rich and balanced, with a fairly smooth medium full-bodied mouthfeel thats slightly warming and pleasant for the abv. Smells better than it tastes, but great beer nonetheless.

On tap: The aroma consists of moderate chocolate, vanilla, coconut, whiskey, and a touch of molasses. Its a dark brown with some faint orange highlights and a small beige head that fades to a thick ring. The flavor starts with moderate chocolate, caramel, and a touch if molasses. The finish has roasted malt, vanilla, coconut, and whiskey. Its medium-full bodied with mild carbonation and a somewhat oily mouthfeel.

Tap at bells, what a fantastic beer, aroma is whiskey, chocolate, vanilla, and some sweet fruits. Taste is big whiskey, chocolate, vanilla, sweet fruits, and some subtle spices. World class

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Tap at hopcat, wow awesome that I walked in on this, tons of whiskey , chocolate and sweet fruits... so smooth and so damn drinkable.... fantastic

From notes. Enjoyed at the MGB Summer Beer Fest. Oh man, this was one I was looking forward to! The pour is a thinner looking dark brown with a thin film of khaki head that dissipates quickly. The aroma is really boozy. Behind that, its really good. There is a great oak and a strong vanilla carrying it. There is a light roast and some basic chocolate before the whiskey presents itself on the back end. The barrel really carries this, as youd imagine. The flavor is much of the same. There is a wonderful oak and vanilla. The chocolate and a light roast take a back seat, and the whiskey really comes through on the back end. The mouth feel is excellent. Its quite thick and viscous with a soft carbonation and a lingeringly chocolatey, roasty, boozy aftertaste.

Draft. Poured black color with an average frothy brown head that mostly lasted with fair lacing. Moderate to heavy roasted malt, chocolate, vanilla, wood, and dark alcohol aroma. Medium to full body with a smooth texture and flat carbonation. Medium to heavy roasted malt and alcohol flavor with a medium to heavy sweet smooth alcohol burn finish of moderate to long duration. This is a standout beer.
Pours coffee like, with no head. Aroma of vanilla, bourbon, and malts. Taste is the same with some cola and molasses. Remarkable smooth yet flavorful.
Draft. Pours a dark brown. Aroma and taste are vanilla, chocolate, bourbon, and roasted goodness.

On tap a tMaduro pre 2015 GTMW event, one of the best beers we had all weekend and it was at our first stop! Pours a very dark brown almost black with a brown head and sticky lacing, the aroma is full of chocolate, roast and a good mixture of vanilla with a hint of whiskey, the flavor is full of vanilla and chocolate with the barrel showing in the finish, completely hides the abv, so good.

Draft to snifter pour opaque black with thin tan head. Nose sweet malt, light whiskey, some dark fruit and light roast. Nose is a little muted compared to the flavors. Taste super sweet, almost Karo syrup sweet, but nice. Some dark fruit and then hot chocolate. Barrel adds nice complexity instead of overpowering. More sweet and light roast in the finish.
On tap at MBGSF 2015. A dark brown pour with a light tan head. Aromas of molasses, cocoa, and bourbon. Rich cocoa flavor, molasses, and bourbon. Great!

Live Rate,
Deal w/ it


Pours basically black with a small but well retained head & some decent lacing on the glass. 

The aroma is loads of dark fruit & bourbon. Its got a nice bit of chocolate & roast with a noticeable enough booziness.

The flavor is pleasantly sweet with a nice coconut,
dark chocolate & roasty bitterness for balance. There is a great vanilla & bourbon element to it thats not totally overbearing. 

The mouthfeel is huge & palate coating but the bitterness lends a nice zippiness that works well in tandem with the thickness of it all.
 Gracious this is fantastic.

On tap at Eccentric. Dark brown body with incredible aromas of vanilla, chocolate and a whiff of whiskey. The whiskey presence is muted enough (in the nose and on the palate) to make this one about the complexity of the wonderful milk chocolate and vanilla of the base beer. This is one that should be bottled and sent directly to my house!!!
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA
